awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tracking Middle-late Paleozoic Global-ocean Redox Conditions Using U Isotopes in Marine Carbonates
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the funded proposal is to determine the relative amounts of oxygen dissolved in ancient oceans during a unique geologic time interval (300 to 420 million years ago) when three major mass extinctions occurred and the Earth was significantly warmer than today. Understanding the history of oxygen levels in ancient oceans is important because oxygen concentrations influence all marine animal life, control the formation and preservation of petroleum and many economic mineral deposits, and affect important biochemical reactions in the oceans and atmosphere. This project utilizes the relatively new geochemical tool of uranium isotopes to develop the most detailed history of changing ocean oxygen concentrations to date. The funding supports the training of the next generation of Earth scientists, will provide hands-on field and laboratory experience for first-generation college students, and will support multiple primary school science teachers to conduct real-world science to gain confidence and provide new ideas for their own classrooms.    

The project goal is to develop a global-ocean redox curve using U isotopes from Devonian-Mississippian marine carbonates. The ~100 million year study interval, which bridges the transition between poorly oxygenated Precambrian-Early Paleozoic oceans and well-oxygenated Late Paleozoic-Recent oceans, is important because of: 1) a doubling of atmospheric pO2 levels, 2) a transition from greenhouse to icehouse climate and intensifying ocean circulation, 3) the occurrence of three mass extinctions, two of which are attributed to marine anoxia, and 4) multiple large positive 13C excursions.  The U-isotope composition of marine carbonates has the potential to record mean global-ocean redox conditions owing to the long residence time (~500 thousand years) of U in seawater.  Samples will be collected from biostratigraphically well-dated successions in Nevada and Utah at spacings ranging from ~100 thousand years/sample to <20 thousand years/sample through specific event intervals. To assess samples for local redox influences, we will analyze redox-sensitive metals, Fe-speciation, and Corg:P ratios. To verify the global nature of the composite curve, we will sample and compare to selected shorter stratigraphic intervals on other continents.

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes and intellectual merit:

The middle Paleozoic (~420-350 million years ago) is particularly interesting because there is evidence for a major increase in ocean-atmosphere oxygen levels (an oxygenation event) but the timing and execution of this event have not been well understood. The overarching goal of this project was to develop a high resolution global redox curve extending ~70 million years for the middle Paleozoic so as to better understand the timing and possible drivers of this oxygenation event. This was achieved through the analysis of carefully collected marine limestone samples and the determination of uranium isotopes that can record a global signal for ocean reducing conditions. To ascertain whether the uranium isotopes were recording a local or global signal, samples representing the same time period were obtained from several different locations (Nevada and Illinois, USA) and other geochemical tracers, such as redox sensitive trace metals, were used to assist in the interpretation of local redox conditions. A subset of samples was also used to determine whether the type of dissolution procedure used for the marine limestone samples might bias the uranium isotope data or contribute to the contamination of the primary uranium signal through the dissolution of other ancillary phases.

Results from studying the rock layers and other geochemical tracers support the interpretation of the uranium isotope record from Nevada as a near-primary record of global ocean oxygen levels that was not influenced by local changes in oxygen or reducing conditions. The uranium isotope trends point to the existence of a major oxygenation event ~395 million years ago, with more oxic seawater conditions over the subsequent 30 million years. The timing of this oxygenation event suggests that the rise in oxygen was the result of the diversification of land-based plants.

Broader impact:

Seven undergraduate student researchers have been involved in this project over the life of the grant. They worked directly and closely with PI Morford and most of the students also collaborated with the co-PIs from the grant. Three students participated in field work with co-PIs Drs. Maya Elrick and Geoff Gilleaudeau, while also developing analysis techniques at F&M. Two students applied and expanded on these analysis techniques at F&M and collaborated with co-PI Stephen Romaniello at Arizona State University, where they were also able to experience research at an R1 institution. In addition to contributing to data analysis, two students also developed and refined a series of interactive activities for young children (preschool to fifth grade) that were shared with the community through our local nature and science museum.

Building on knowledge from courses and lab/field experiences, these transformative undergraduate research opportunities engaged students in the creative scientific process. Of the seven students who completed 8 or 10-week summer research experiences, two students continued their research for an additional one or two semesters for academic credit. All of the students have graduated from F&M; two are currently in graduate school (Masters and PhD programs), two have completed Masters degrees, and three are in science-related professional positions.
